articles.headline: The ‘Rocket Docket’ Judge Who Will Decide the Fate of Google’s Ad Technology
articles.snippet: The ruling by a federal judge, Leonie Brinkema, in an antitrust case over Google’s advertising technology could add to the internet company’s woes.
articles.abstract: The ruling by a federal judge, Leonie Brinkema, in an antitrust case over Google’s advertising technology could add to the internet company’s woes.
articles.lead_paragraph: During a trial in a Virginia courtroom in September over Google’s dominance in advertising technology, concepts and phrases like a “second-price auction," “demand-side platforms” and “header bidding” repeatedly came up.
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Nico Grant

articles.headline: An A.I. Granny Is Phone Scammers’ Worst Nightmare
articles.snippet: Daisy Harris, an A.I.-generated English granny, has been stymying scammers with meandering, time-wasting conversations. But can she actually make a dent in the flood of fraud?
articles.abstract: Daisy Harris, an A.I.-generated English granny, has been stymying scammers with meandering, time-wasting conversations. But can she actually make a dent in the flood of fraud?
articles.lead_paragraph: Daisy Harris likes birds — there’s one outside her window. Her cat is named Fluffy, and she’d love to tell you about her knitting hobby. She likes tea and biscuits. And she just can’t seem to figure out this internet thing.

articles.headline: In Haiti, a Grim Barometer: Even United Nations Workers Are Fleeing
articles.snippet: A surge in gang violence over the past two weeks has led international aid organizations to rethink their staff levels in Haiti.
articles.abstract: A surge in gang violence over the past two weeks has led international aid organizations to rethink their staff levels in Haiti.
articles.lead_paragraph: A United Nations helicopter has been buzzing nonstop for days over Haiti, as the U.N. starts to draw down its personnel in Port-au-Prince, evacuating 14 people at a time in chopper rides.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles and David C. Adams

articles.headline: Jack Smith Seeks Dismissal of Two Federal Cases Against Trump
articles.snippet: The special counsel effectively brought to a close the Justice Department efforts to hold Donald J. Trump accountable in the election and classified documents cases.
articles.abstract: The special counsel effectively brought to a close the Justice Department efforts to hold Donald J. Trump accountable in the election and classified documents cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: The special counsel Jack Smith asked two courts on Monday to effectively shut down the federal criminal cases he brought against President-elect Donald J. Trump last year, bowing to a Justice Department policy that says it is unconstitutional to pursue prosecutions against sitting presidents.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer, Charlie Savage and Devlin Barrett

articles.headline: Top Trump Aide Accused of Asking for Money to ‘Promote’ Potential Appointees
articles.snippet: President-elect Donald J. Trump ordered the investigation by his legal team into Boris Epshteyn, a powerful figure in the transition. Mr. Epshteyn denies the allegations.
articles.abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump ordered the investigation by his legal team into Boris Epshteyn, a powerful figure in the transition. Mr. Epshteyn denies the allegations.
articles.lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s legal team found evidence that a top adviser asked for retainer fees from potential appointees in order to promote them for jobs in the new administration, five people briefed on the matter said on Monday.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan

articles.headline: The World’s Pioneering Tech Cop Is Making Her Exit
articles.snippet: Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s antitrust regulator, who put technology’s harms on the global agenda, reflected on a decade of taking on the biggest companies and what comes next.
articles.abstract: Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s antitrust regulator, who put technology’s harms on the global agenda, reflected on a decade of taking on the biggest companies and what comes next.
articles.lead_paragraph: Margrethe Vestager, the European Union antitrust enforcer who has been the world’s foremost critic of the tech industry, recently walked through her Brussels office wondering what to do with the stuff she had accumulated during a decade in that role, which ends late this month. At one point, she paused to lift a sculpture of a hand holding up its middle finger.

articles.headline: China’s Police Are Preying on Small Firms in Search of Cash
articles.snippet: With localities facing budget holes, the police are crossing provincial borders to collect fines and draining company treasuries. Businesses call it a shakedown.
articles.abstract: With localities facing budget holes, the police are crossing provincial borders to collect fines and draining company treasuries. Businesses call it a shakedown.
articles.lead_paragraph: In April 2023, police officers from a city in southern Guangdong Province traveled 600 miles north to Wuhan, detained 25 employees of a social media company and coerced its finance staff to transfer more than $41 million to accounts associated with the police.

articles.headline: Colombia and Venezuela Have a Beef: Who Owns the, or Makes the Best, Arepa?
articles.snippet: Both countries claim the cornbread as their own. But where does it really come from? And who makes it better?
articles.abstract: Both countries claim the cornbread as their own. But where does it really come from? And who makes it better?
articles.lead_paragraph: A heated and longstanding rivalry simmers between neighbors Colombia and Venezuela — not over politics, migration or even soccer, but over the humble arepa.

articles.headline: Transgender Activists Question the Movement’s Confrontational Approach
articles.snippet: Facing diminishing public support, some activists say all-or-nothing tactics are not working. “We have to make it OK for someone to change their minds.”
articles.abstract: Facing diminishing public support, some activists say all-or-nothing tactics are not working. “We have to make it OK for someone to change their minds.”
articles.lead_paragraph: To get on the wrong side of transgender activists is often to endure their unsparing criticism.

articles.headline: After Trump’s Tariff Threat, Is a China Currency War Next?
articles.snippet: While China could offset American tariffs by letting its currency fall, that might endanger Beijing’s recent efforts to stabilize the economy.
articles.abstract: While China could offset American tariffs by letting its currency fall, that might endanger Beijing’s recent efforts to stabilize the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Beijing has a powerful tool for responding to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threatened new tariffs on Chinese goods: It could start a currency war, a step that poses formidable risks for China as well as the United States.

articles.headline: Walmart, Once Eager to Promote Diversity, Pulls Back Amid Conservative Pressure
articles.snippet: Among other things, the retailer will no longer use the term D.E.I.
articles.abstract: Among other things, the retailer will no longer use the term D.E.I.
articles.lead_paragraph: In June of 2020, as protesters spilled into the streets after the murder of George Floyd, Walmart’s chief executive, Doug McMillon, promised action.
articles.byline: By Lauren Hirsch, Emma Goldberg and Jordyn Holman
